IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: TO SUPPORT NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY ON GIFT PLANNING METHODS, ENSURE THE FUTURE OF NONPROFITS AND THE SERVICES TO OUR JEWISH AND SECULAR COMMUNITIES.
IRS990.MissionDescription: THE FOUNDATION IS DEDICATED TO ENSURING THAT SYNAGOGUES AND JEWISH AGENCIES WILL BE THERE IN THE FUTURE SO THAT GENERATIONS TO COME WILL BE ABLE TO ENJOY THE RICH JEWISH HERITAGE AND TRADITIONS.
IRS990.Description: CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS TO VARIOUS NATIONAL, REGIONAL, AND LOCAL JEWISH WELFARE, PHILANTHROPIC, AND CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS.

OtherSecurities.Description: CASH SURRENDER VALUE OF LIFE INSURANCE
PRESENT VALUE OF FUTURE INTEREST IN CHARITABLE REMAINDER TRUSTS

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Selected Temporarily and Permanently Restricted Endowment Assets: During the years 1995 through 1999, the Foundation became the trustee and remainder beneficiary in three charitable remainder trusts. Under the terms of the trust agreements, the Foundation, in its capacity as trustee, is required to make payments to the donors in each taxable year during the lifetime of the donor, in amounts ranging from 5% to 7% of the fair value of the trust assets as of the first day of each taxable year. These payments are made in quarterly installments. Upon the death of the donor, the remainder assets of the trust are normally distributed to the Foundation for its general purposes. As of June 30, 2010 and 2009, a valuation of the remainder interests was performed using published life expectancy tables and an assumed rate of growth of the trust assets of 5%. During 2007, the donor of one of the charitable remainder trusts died and the value of the account at the time of death was transferred to the Foundation. The Foundation entered into an agreement with the decedent's children to establish a perpetual endowment with the funds received from the charitable remainder trust. The amount of the endowment created was $62,613. During 1995, the Foundation received trust assets from the Jacksonville Jewish Federation which were invested in a money market account and mutual funds. The donor restricted the gift to be used to establish a perpetual endowment. The endowment is restricted to be used to support the Jacksonville Jewish Federation, Jewish Community Alliance and Beth Shalom congregation. Once the fund reached $75,000, then every January, five percent of the account value at December 31 of the previous year must be distributed evenly between the beneficiaries. No distributions shall be made if the fund falls below $75,000. There were no distributions during the years ended June 30, 2010 and 2009. During November 1999, the Foundation received a gift of cash, which was invested in marketable securities and a money market account. The donor restricted the gift to be used to establish a perpetual endowment. Earnings on the account are restricted for use by the Jewish Family and Community Services. There were $7,464 and $7,961 in distributions during the years ended June 30, 2010 and 2009, respectively. During December 2000, the Foundation received a gift of cash, which was invested in marketable securities and a money market account. The donor restricted the gift to be used to establish a perpetual endowment to be used to support the National Council of Jewish Women. Five percent of the account value at June 30th of the previous fiscal year may be distributed. There were no distributions during the year ended June 30, 2010, and $275 in distributions during the year ended June 30, 2009. During October 2002, the Foundation received a gift of cash, which was invested in marketable securities. The donor restricted the gift to be used to establish a perpetual endowment to be used to support enrollees in the Jewish Community Alliance Early Childhood and Camp Programs. Only the interest income may be distributed and only after the passing of both donors. There were no distributions during the years ended June 30, 2010 and 2009. During 2004, the Foundation received a gift of cash, which was invested in a money market account. The donor restricted the gift to be used to establish a perpetual endowment. Earnings on the account are restricted for use in the community of Slutsk for reclamation of Jewish headstones and other cemetery related Jewish programming. No distributions shall be made until the fund reaches the minimum endowment balance. There were no distributions during the years ended June 30, 2010 and 2009. During 2007, the Foundation received a gift of cash, which was invested in marketable securities. The donor restricted the gift to be used to establish a perpetual endowment. Earnings on the account are restricted for use by the Gainesville Hillel, Inc. There were $1,500 distributions during the year ended June 30, 2010 and $3,000 in distributions during the year ended June 30, 2009. During 2010 and 2009, the Foundation received various individual donations and a grant from a private institution to fund the Create a Jewish Legacy program. These funds are restricted for the operations of this program. The program had unspent funds of $24,059 and $8,439 at June 30, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
UNREALIZED GAIN ON INVESTMENTS: 133565. CHANGE IN VALUE OF CHARITABLE REMAINDER TRUSTS: -821.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: Executive director monitors use of funds in accordance with Organization's purpose. In addition to the purposes of the Foundation expressed in its bylaws, donors may suggest and the Board of Trustees may authorize distributions to organizations that do not directly benefit the Jacksonville community or Jewish causes if the beneficiary is a qualified 501(c)(3) organization.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 2
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Trustees Barbara Jaffe and Sandy Zimmerman have a family relationship. They are mother and son.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 6
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The initial members of the Corporation were Jacksonville Jewish Federation Inc, Beth El-The Beaches Synagogue, Beth Shalom Congregation, Congregation Ahavath Chesed, Etz Chaim Synagogue, Jacksonville Jewish Center, Jewish Community Alliance, Jewish Family & Community Services, and River Garden Hebrew Home. Per the bylaws of the Corporation, any organization organized and operated exclusively for charitable, education, religious, or scientific purposes qualified as an exempt organization under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code that is based in Jacksonville, Florida and has strong ties to the Jewish community may be elected to membership in the Corporation by a 75% vote of the Members present at any annual or special meeting.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Each Member of the Corporation shall designate a person to serve as a Trustee of the Corporation, Additional Trustees are elected by the Members of the Corporation.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: A draft of form 990 is presented to the Board of Directors and the Audit Committee for approval prior to being finalized and filed with the IRS.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The treasurer of the organization researches salary ranges and makes recommendation to the Board of Directors. The Board of Directors meets annually to review and approve or deny the salary recommendations.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Foundation's governing documents and financial statements are available for public inspection upon request at their office in Jacksonville at 4932 Sunbeam Road.
The organization has not changed its oversight of the audit or its selection of an independent accountant.
